elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with trimesic acid (H3BTC) at different pH conditions yield two coordination polymers of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3(NH3)4] n ·2nH2O (1) and [Cu4(BTC)2(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4] n (2). Crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a three-fold parallel interpenetration network and complex 2 shows a two-dimensional bilayer structure. Crystal data are orthorhombic, space group Pbcn, a = 11.242(3) Å, b = 16.963(4) Å, c = 13.898(4) Å, Z = 4 for 1 and monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 18.887(4) Å, b = 10.761(2) Å, c = 14.488(3) Å, β = 126.100(3)°, Z = 4 for 2.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O with trimesic acid (H3BTC) at different pH conditions yield two coordination polymers of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3(NH3)4] n ⋅2nH2O (1) and [Cu4(BTC)2(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4] n  (2). Crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a three-fold parallel interpenetration network and complex 2 shows a two-dimensional bilayer structure. Crystal data are orthorhombic, space group Pbcn, a = 11.242(3) Å, b = 16.963(4) Å, c = 13.898(4) Å, Z = 4 for 1 and monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 18.887(4) Å, b = 10.761(2) Å, c = 14.488(3) Å, β = 126.100(3)°, Z = 4 for 2.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with trimesic acid (H3BTC) at different pH conditions yield two coordination polymers exhibiting a three-fold parallel interpenetration network and bilayer structure.
elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O with trimesic acid (H3BTC) at different pH conditions yield two coordination polymers exhibiting a three-fold parallel interpenetration network and bilayer structure.

elements.content: The design and assembly of metal-involved supramolecular architectures based on crystal engineering are currently of great interest in the field of supramelocular chemistry and material science because they can provide intriguing architectures and functional materials. Polycarboxylate aromatic ligands, such as 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), trimesic acid (H3BTC), and 1,2,4,5-benzeneteracarvoxylic acid (H4BTEC), represent an important kind of functional molecular building unit in the assembly of supramoleular architectures. The versatile coordination modes of the carboxylates as well as the chemical robustness of these kinds of ligands not only leads to the assembled framework exhibiting structural diversity but also benefits the thermal stability of the framework. Owing to the relatively weak coordination bonding in coordination complexes (as compared with the strong covalent bonds in organic compounds), however, the coordination modes of polycarboxylate aromatic ligands are markedly sensitive to external physical or chemical stimuli. Thus, investigation of the influence of each individual factor on coordination modes of these ligands is valuable to expand the structure while preserving the framework topology by increasing the ligand length to generate “isoreticular” materials. Although a large number of polycarboxylates-based coordination polymers have been synthesized, investigation of external physical or chemical stimuli effects on the structures of polycarboxylate-based coordination polymers remains rare. Here we report the syntheses of two copper(II)/BTC coordination polymers, i.e., a three-fold parallel interpenetration network of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3(NH3)4] n ·2nH2O (1) and a bilayer structure of [Cu4(BTC)2(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4] n (2), under different pH conditions. Their structural difference clearly shows a structural response to the pH value of the reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and assembly of metal-involved supramolecular architectures based on crystal engineering are currently of great interest in the field of supramelocular chemistry and material science because they can provide intriguing architectures and functional materials. Polycarboxylate aromatic ligands, such as 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid (H2BDC), trimesic acid (H3BTC), and 1,2,4,5-benzeneteracarvoxylic acid (H4BTEC), represent an important kind of functional molecular building unit in the assembly of supramoleular architectures. The versatile coordination modes of the carboxylates as well as the chemical robustness of these kinds of ligands not only leads to the assembled framework exhibiting structural diversity but also benefits the thermal stability of the framework. Owing to the relatively weak coordination bonding in coordination complexes (as compared with the strong covalent bonds in organic compounds), however, the coordination modes of polycarboxylate aromatic ligands are markedly sensitive to external physical or chemical stimuli. Thus, investigation of the influence of each individual factor on coordination modes of these ligands is valuable to expand the structure while preserving the framework topology by increasing the ligand length to generate "isoreticular" materials. Although a large number of polycarboxylates-based coordination polymers have been synthesized, investigation of external physical or chemical stimuli effects on the structures of polycarboxylate-based coordination polymers remains rare. Here we report the syntheses of two copper(II)/BTC coordination polymers, i.e., a three-fold parallel interpenetration network of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3(NH3)4] n ⋅2nH2O (1) and a bilayer structure of [Cu4(BTC)2(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4] n  (2), under different pH conditions. Their structural difference clearly shows a structural response to the pH value of the reaction.

elements.content:
Crystal Data and Details of the Data Collection and Refinement for Complexes1 and 2

complex 1 2 formula Cu3C18H28N4O17 Cu4C18H24O16N4 fw 763.06 806.57 cryst system orthorhombic monoclinic space group Pbcn C2/c a (Å) 11.242(3) 18.887(4) b (Å) 16.963(4) 10.761(2) c (Å) 13.898(4) 14.488(3) α (°) 90 90 β (°) 90 126.100(3) γ (°) 90 90 V (Å3) 2650.2(11) 2379.1(8) Z 4 4 T (K) 123 123 D calcd (g·cm-3) 1.912 2.252 μ (mm-1) 2.475 3.622 indep reflns 2188 2312 absd reflns 2017 2223 number of parameters 199 214 R 1 [I > 2σ(I)] 0.0789 0.0257 wR 2[I > 2σ(I)] 0.1854 0.0692 R 1 (all data) 0.0850 0.0268 wR 2 (all data) 0.1899 0.0699

Materials and Methods. All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were analytical grade and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrometer using the KBr pellet technique. Elemental analysis was carried out on a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. An X-ray powder diffractometry (XRPD) study of complex 2 was performed on Panalytical X-Pert pro diffractometer with Cu−Kα radiation. Magnetic susceptibility was measured by a Quantum Design MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

 Materials and Methods. All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were analytical grade and used without further purification. Infrared spectra were recorded with a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrometer using the KBr pellet technique. Elemental analysis was carried out on a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. An X-ray powder diffractometry (XRPD) study of complex 2 was performed on Panalytical X-Pert pro diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation. Magnetic susceptibility was measured by a Quantum Design MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID).

elements.content: Syntheses. [Cu 3 (BTC) 2 (H 2 O) 3 (NH 3 ) 4 ] n · 2 n H 2 O (1). To 12 mL of aqua-ethanol (water/ethanol = 1:1 (v/v)) solution was added Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.435 g, 1.8 mmol) and H3BTC (1.0 mmol) while stirring. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 8.3 with NH3·H2O (1.0 mol·L-1), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr and heated in an autoclave at 180 °C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C·h-1. Dark blue crystals of 1 were obtained in 27.6% yield based on H3BTC. Anal. Calcd for Cu3C18H28N4O17 (%):  C, 28.31; H, 3.67; N, 5.24. Found:  C, 27.95; H, 3.69; N, 5.58. FTIR (KBr, cm-1):  3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w.
elements.clean_text: Syntheses. [Cu  3  (BTC)  2  (H  2  O)  3  (NH  3  )  4  ]   n   ⋅ 2  n  H  2  O (1). To 12 mL of aqua-ethanol (water/ethanol = 1:1 (v/v)) solution was added Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.435 g, 1.8 mmol) and H3BTC (1.0 mmol) while stirring. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 8.3 with NH3⋅H2O (1.0 mol⋅L-1), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr and heated in an autoclave at 180 °C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1. Dark blue crystals of 1 were obtained in 27.6% yield based on H3BTC. Anal. Calcd for Cu3C18H28N4O17 (%): C, 28.31; H, 3.67; N, 5.24. Found: C, 27.95; H, 3.69; N, 5.58. FTIR (KBr, cm-1): 3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w.

elements.content: [Cu 4 (BTC) 2 (OH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (NH 3 ) 4 ] n (2). Complex 2 was prepared in a similar way as illustrated for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction adjusted to 9.2. Prism-like blue crystals of 2 were obtained in 40.2% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Anal. Calcd for Cu4C18H24O16N4 (%):  C, 26.78; H, 2.97; N, 6.94; Found:  C, 26.86; H, 2.92; N, 6.88. FTIR (KBr, cm-1):  3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w. The agreement of experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns with simulated ones for 2 (Supporting Information, Figure ) indicates that a single phase of 2 is obtained.
elements.clean_text: [Cu  4  (BTC)  2  (OH)  2  (H  2  O)  2  (NH  3  )  4  ]   n    (2). Complex 2 was prepared in a similar way as illustrated for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction adjusted to 9.2. Prism-like blue crystals of 2 were obtained in 40.2% yield based on Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. Anal. Calcd for Cu4C18H24O16N4 (%): C, 26.78; H, 2.97; N, 6.94; Found: C, 26.86; H, 2.92; N, 6.88. FTIR (KBr, cm-1): 3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w. The agreement of experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns with simulated ones for 2 (Supporting Information, Figure ) indicates that a single phase of 2 is obtained.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Data collections were performed on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer at 123 K for 1 and 2. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically (C−H, 0.96 Å, N−H, 0.90 Å). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for the complexes are summarized in Table .

Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2  using the SHELXTL program. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated geometrically (C-H, 0.96 Å, N-H, 0.90 Å). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for the complexes are summarized in Table .

elements.content: Description of Crystal Structures. Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn and consists of three copper(II) cations, two BTC ligands, four ammonia, and five water molecules. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that there are two crystallographically independent copper(II) cations, Cu1 and Cu2, in 1. Cu1 is six-coordinated by two ammonia molecules and two chelate carboxylates from two BTC units in distorted octahedral geometry, and Cu2 is five-coordinated by three water molecules and two monodentate carboxylates from two different BTC units in distorted square-pyramidal geometry as shown in Figure . The bond distances Cu−Ocarboxylate and Cu−N in octahedral geometry are 1.945(5)−2.790(8) and 1.965(7)−1.975(5) Å, respectively. The bond lengths of Cu−Ocarboxylate and Cu−Owater are 1.958(5) and 2.005(6)−2.279(9) Å in square-pyramidal geometry. The bond lengths of Cu−Ocarboxylate and Cu−Owater are comparable to those usually encountered for copper−oxygen coordination. Each BTC ligand serves as a three-connected node to coordinate with three copper(II) ions through its two carboxylates in chelate mode and one in monodentate mode, generating a two-dimensional (2D) honeycomb network with 7.4 × 10.2 Å cavities as shown in Figure . As is usually found in metal−organic frameworks containing large cavities that allow interpenetration, interlocking the 2D network leads to a three-fold parallel interpenetration network as illustrated in Figure . It was noted that, although the topology of the 2D network in 1 is similar to the previously reported coordination polymers of Ni3(btc)2(py)9(H2O)3 (py = pyridine) and [Cu3(Ph2SNH)6(tma)2] (tma = 1,3,5-benzentricarboxylates), there is a significant difference in the structure among the complexes. In the complex of Ni3(btc)2(py)9(H2O)3 and [Cu3(Ph2SNH)6(tma)2], the interpenetration was restricted due to pyridine ligands projecting perpendicularly to the cavities from adjacent layers and the phenyl group of Ph2SNH locating in the cavities of the 2D honeycomb network. The adjacent three interpenetrating networks are further connected through coordinated ammonia molecules from one layer hydrogen-bonded to the carboxylate group from the adjacent layer (N(1)−H(1B)···O(2) = 3.174(10) Å, H(1B)···O(2) = 2.32 Å, <N(1)−H(1B)···O(2) = 156.0°, N(1)−H(1C) ···O(4) = 3.221(9) Å, H(1C)···O(4) = 2.38 Å, <N(1)−H(1C) ···O(4) = 153.5°), generating a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network as illustrated in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Description of Crystal Structures. Complex 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group Pbcn and consists of three copper(II) cations, two BTC ligands, four ammonia, and five water molecules. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that there are two crystallographically independent copper(II) cations, Cu1 and Cu2, in 1. Cu1 is six-coordinated by two ammonia molecules and two chelate carboxylates from two BTC units in distorted octahedral geometry, and Cu2 is five-coordinated by three water molecules and two monodentate carboxylates from two different BTC units in distorted square-pyramidal geometry as shown in Figure . The bond distances Cu-Ocarboxylate and Cu-N in octahedral geometry are 1.945(5)-2.790(8) and 1.965(7)-1.975(5) Å, respectively. The bond lengths of Cu-Ocarboxylate and Cu-Owater are 1.958(5) and 2.005(6)-2.279(9) Å in square-pyramidal geometry. The bond lengths of Cu-Ocarboxylate and Cu-Owater are comparable to those usually encountered for copper-oxygen coordination. Each BTC ligand serves as a three-connected node to coordinate with three copper(II) ions through its two carboxylates in chelate mode and one in monodentate mode, generating a two-dimensional (2D) honeycomb network with 7.4 × 10.2 Å cavities as shown in Figure . As is usually found in metal-organic frameworks containing large cavities that allow interpenetration, interlocking the 2D network leads to a three-fold parallel interpenetration network as illustrated in Figure . It was noted that, although the topology of the 2D network in 1 is similar to the previously reported coordination polymers of Ni3(btc)2(py)9(H2O)3  (py = pyridine) and [Cu3(Ph2SNH)6(tma)2] (tma = 1,3,5-benzentricarboxylates), there is a significant difference in the structure among the complexes. In the complex of Ni3(btc)2(py)9(H2O)3 and [Cu3(Ph2SNH)6(tma)2], the interpenetration was restricted due to pyridine ligands projecting perpendicularly to the cavities from adjacent layers and the phenyl group of Ph2SNH locating in the cavities of the 2D honeycomb network. The adjacent three interpenetrating networks are further connected through coordinated ammonia molecules from one layer hydrogen-bonded to the carboxylate group from the adjacent layer (N(1)-H(1B)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 3.174(10) Å, H(1B)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 2.32 Å, <N(1)-H(1B)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 156.0°, N(1)-H(1C) ⋅⋅⋅O(4) = 3.221(9) Å, H(1C)⋅⋅⋅O(4) = 2.38 Å, <N(1)-H(1C) ⋅⋅⋅O(4) = 153.5°), generating a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network as illustrated in Figure .

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group C2/c. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit in 2 consists of two independent copper(II) cations, one BTC ligand, one μ3-hydroxyl group, one water molecule, and two ammonia molecules. Of the two independent copper(II) centers, one (Cu1) is located in a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different BTC ligands; one μ3-hydroxyl ligand occupied the equatorial positions and one μ3-hydroxyl group and one ammonia molecule occupied the apical positions. The other (Cu2) is located in a distorted octahedron geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different BTC ligands, with one μ3-hydroxyl ligand and one ammonia molecule at basal positions, and one water and one monodentate carboxylate group at apical positions as shown in Figure . Two independent copper(II) centers bridged by a hydroxyl group and a carboxylate in syn−syn fashion form a [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2(O2C−)3] unit. Two [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2 (O2C−)3] units are further linked through the coordination of the hydroxyl and carboxylate groups in one [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2(O2C−)3] unit to the copper(II) ion from the other [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2(O2C−)3] unit, which generates a SUB of [Cu4(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4(O2C−)6] in which the tetranuclear copper(II) cluster of [Cu4(OH)2] exhibits a chair-shaped configuration as shown in Figure . The solid structure of 2 can be viewed as an extension of the [Cu4(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4 (O2C−)6] SUB into a bilayer structure (Figure ), which is significantly different from that formed by [Zn4(OH)2(O2C−)6] SUB, in which the complex exhibits a 3D two-fold interpenetrating structure. The adjacent bilayers are further linked through a coordinated ammonia molecule from one layer hydrogen-bonded to the carboxylate group from an adjacent one (N(1)−H(1)···O(6) = 3.038(3) Å, H(1)···O(6) = 2.26(4) Å, <N(1)−H(1)···O(6) = 170(3)°, N(1)−H(2)···O(3) = 3.152(3) Å, H(2)···O(3) = 2.50(5) Å, <N(1)−H(2)···O(3) = 144(4)°, N(2)−H(6)···O(2) = 3.125(3) Å, H(6)···O(2) = 2.35(4) Å, <N(2)−H(6)···O(2) = 159(3)°), as well as through the coordinated water molecules (O3w) from one bilayer hydrogen-bonded to the carboxylate group from adjacent layers (O(3W)−H(3WA) ···O(6) = 2.882(3) Å, H(3WA)···O(6) = 2.40 Å, <O(3W)−H(3WA)···O(6) = 116.6°, O(3W)−H(3WB)···O(3) = 2.967(3) Å, H(3WB)···O(3) = 2.19 Å, <O(3W)−H(3WB)···O(3) = 152.5°), which generates a 3D supramolecular architecture as illustrated in Figure . It was noted that although the bilayer architecture was common in the assembly of T-shaped building blocks, it is rarely observed when other types of building blocks are used. The bond lengths of Cu−O are 1.915−2.588. The Cu···Cu distances are 3.202, 3.056, 3.471, and 5.938 Å for Cu1A···Cu2, Cu1···Cu1A, Cu1···Cu2, and Cu2···Cu2A pairs, respectively, which is different from those of 3.394, 3.164, 3.131, 5.712 Å, in chair-shaped tetranuclear copper(II) clusters previously reported.
elements.clean_text: Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group C2/c. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit in 2 consists of two independent copper(II) cations, one BTC ligand, one μ3-hydroxyl group, one water molecule, and two ammonia molecules. Of the two independent copper(II) centers, one (Cu1) is located in a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different BTC ligands; one μ3-hydroxyl ligand occupied the equatorial positions and one μ3-hydroxyl group and one ammonia molecule occupied the apical positions. The other (Cu2) is located in a distorted octahedron geometry with two oxygen atoms from two different BTC ligands, with one μ3-hydroxyl ligand and one ammonia molecule at basal positions, and one water and one monodentate carboxylate group at apical positions as shown in Figure . Two independent copper(II) centers bridged by a hydroxyl group and a carboxylate in syn-syn fashion form a [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2(O2C-)3] unit. Two [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2 (O2C-)3] units are further linked through the coordination of the hydroxyl and carboxylate groups in one [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2(O2C-)3] unit to the copper(II) ion from the other [Cu2(OH)(H2O)(NH3)2(O2C-)3] unit, which generates a SUB of [Cu4(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4(O2C-)6] in which the tetranuclear copper(II) cluster of [Cu4(OH)2] exhibits a chair-shaped configuration as shown in Figure . The solid structure of 2 can be viewed as an extension of the [Cu4(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4 (O2C-)6] SUB into a bilayer structure (Figure ), which is significantly different from that formed by [Zn4(OH)2(O2C-)6] SUB, in which the complex exhibits a 3D two-fold interpenetrating structure. The adjacent bilayers are further linked through a coordinated ammonia molecule from one layer hydrogen-bonded to the carboxylate group from an adjacent one (N(1)-H(1)⋅⋅⋅O(6) = 3.038(3) Å, H(1)⋅⋅⋅O(6) = 2.26(4) Å, <N(1)-H(1)⋅⋅⋅O(6) = 170(3)°, N(1)-H(2)⋅⋅⋅O(3) = 3.152(3) Å, H(2)⋅⋅⋅O(3) = 2.50(5) Å, <N(1)-H(2)⋅⋅⋅O(3) = 144(4)°, N(2)-H(6)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 3.125(3) Å, H(6)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 2.35(4) Å, <N(2)-H(6)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 159(3)°), as well as through the coordinated water molecules (O3w) from one bilayer hydrogen-bonded to the carboxylate group from adjacent layers (O(3W)-H(3WA) ⋅⋅⋅O(6) = 2.882(3) Å, H(3WA)⋅⋅⋅O(6) = 2.40 Å, <O(3W)-H(3WA)⋅⋅⋅O(6) = 116.6°, O(3W)-H(3WB)⋅⋅⋅O(3) = 2.967(3) Å, H(3WB)⋅⋅⋅O(3) = 2.19 Å, <O(3W)-H(3WB)⋅⋅⋅O(3) = 152.5°), which generates a 3D supramolecular architecture as illustrated in Figure . It was noted that although the bilayer architecture was common in the assembly of T-shaped building blocks, it is rarely observed when other types of building blocks are used. The bond lengths of Cu-O are 1.915-2.588. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances are 3.202, 3.056, 3.471, and 5.938 Å for Cu1A⋅⋅⋅Cu2, Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1A, Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2, and Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2A  pairs, respectively, which is different from those of 3.394, 3.164, 3.131, 5.712 Å, in chair-shaped tetranuclear copper(II) clusters previously reported.

elements.content: On the basis of the synthetic conditions of 1 and 2, the structural differences between 1 and 2 are clearly related to the pH of the reaction. Unlike the reported effect of pH on the structure of complex that is realized through the pH value of the reaction influencing the deprotonation of the organic acid, the pH effect on the structure of the complex in the present work is achieved by introducing a hydroxyl group because the reaction is performed at a high pH value so that the H3BTC is deprotonated completely. Importantly, the introduction of the hydroxyl group not only changes the Cu-to-BTC ratio and results in a structure of 2 that is significantly distinct from that of 1, but it also favors the formation of a polynuclear copper(II) coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the synthetic conditions of 1 and 2, the structural differences between 1 and 2 are clearly related to the pH of the reaction. Unlike the reported effect of pH on the structure of complex that is realized through the pH value of the reaction influencing the deprotonation of the organic acid, the pH effect on the structure of the complex in the present work is achieved by introducing a hydroxyl group because the reaction is performed at a high pH value so that the H3BTC is deprotonated completely. Importantly, the introduction of the hydroxyl group not only changes the Cu-to-BTC ratio and results in a structure of 2 that is significantly distinct from that of 1, but it also favors the formation of a polynuclear copper(II) coordination polymer.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. The magnetic susceptibility of 2 was investigated in the temperature range of 2−300 K at an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The plots of χ M T and χ M -1 vs T are shown in Figure , and the plot of χ M vs T is illustrated in Supporting Information (Figure ). At room temperature, χ M T is 1.62 cm3 mol-1 K (300 K), which is close to the value expected for four uncoupled copper(II) ions with g = 2 (1.5 cm3 mol-1 K). As the temperature decreases, the value of χ M T decreases from 1.62 cm3 mol-1 K, first gradually down to 70 K and then it more markedly reaches a minimum value of 0.03 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. This behavior is indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions between the copper centers. Considering the C 2 v symmetry of the tetranuclear copper(II) in 2, there are four exchange parameters between Cu(II) centers, J 1, J 2, J 3, and J 4; J 1, J 2, and J 3 correspond to single oxygen bridge/μ3-hydroxyl (e.g., Cu1A···Cu2), double μ3-hydroxyl (e.g., Cu1···Cu1A), carboxylate group bridge/μ3-hydroxyl (e.g., Cu1···Cu2), respectively (Scheme ), and J 4 is assumed to be zero due to the large Cu2···Cu2A distance (5.938 Å) (Scheme ). As a consequence of the coupling scheme, the Hamiltonian is H = −2J 1 (S 1 S 3 + S 2 S 4) − 2J 2 S 1 S 2 − 2J 3 (S 1 S 4 + S 2 S 3) − 2J 4 S 3 S 4 (J 4 = 0). The expression for the molar susceptibility is then derived from the above Hamiltonian as24 Here χ tetra = (2Ng 2 β 2/kT)(u/v), N is Avogadro's number, g is the Landé g factor, β is the electron Bohr magneton, k is the Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature in Kelvin, zJ represents the interaction between clusters, u = 5 exp(J 1 / kT + J 2 /2kT + J 3 /kT) + exp(−J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT − J 3 /kT) + exp(−J 2 /2kT − ) + exp(−J 2 /2kT + ), and v = 5 exp(J 1 / kT + J 2 /2kT + J 3 /kT) + 3 exp(−J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT − J 3 /kT) + 3 exp(−J 2 /2kT − ) + 3 exp(−J 2 /2kT + ) + exp(−J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT − J 3 /kT − ) + exp(−J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT − J 3 /kT + ).
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Properties. The magnetic susceptibility of 2 was investigated in the temperature range of 2-300 K at an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. The plots of χ M T and χ M -1 vs T are shown in Figure , and the plot of χ M vs T is illustrated in Supporting Information (Figure ). At room temperature, χ M T is 1.62 cm3 mol-1 K (300 K), which is close to the value expected for four uncoupled copper(II) ions with g = 2 (1.5 cm3 mol-1 K). As the temperature decreases, the value of χ M T decreases from 1.62 cm3 mol-1 K, first gradually down to 70 K and then it more markedly reaches a minimum value of 0.03 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. This behavior is indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions between the copper centers. Considering the C 2  v  symmetry of the tetranuclear copper(II) in 2, there are four exchange parameters between Cu(II) centers, J 1, J 2, J 3, and J 4; J 1, J 2, and J 3 correspond to single oxygen bridge/μ3-hydroxyl (e.g., Cu1A⋅⋅⋅Cu2), double μ3-hydroxyl (e.g., Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu1A), carboxylate group bridge/μ3-hydroxyl (e.g., Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2), respectively (Scheme ), and J 4 is assumed to be zero due to the large Cu2⋅⋅⋅Cu2A distance (5.938 Å) (Scheme ). As a consequence of the coupling scheme, the Hamiltonian is H = -2J 1 (S 1 S 3 + S 2 S 4) - 2J 2 S 1 S 2 - 2J 3 (S 1 S 4 + S 2 S 3) - 2J 4 S 3 S 4 (J 4 = 0). The expression for the molar susceptibility is then derived from the above Hamiltonian as24     Here χ tetra = (2Ng 2 β 2/kT)(u/v), N is Avogadro's number, g is the Landé g factor, β is the electron Bohr magneton, k is the Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature in Kelvin, zJ represents the interaction between clusters, u = 5 exp(J 1 / kT + J 2 /2kT + J 3 /kT) + exp(-J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT - J 3 /kT) + exp(-J 2 /2kT -   ) + exp(-J 2 /2kT +   ), and v = 5 exp(J 1 / kT + J 2 /2kT + J 3 /kT) + 3 exp(-J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT - J 3 /kT) + 3 exp(-J  2  /2kT -   ) + 3 exp(-J 2 /2kT +   ) + exp(-J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT - J 3 /kT -   ) + exp(-J 1 /kT + J 2 /2kT - J 3 /kT +   ).

elements.content: The experimental data were fitted to eq 1 with g, J 1, J 2, J 3, and zJ as fitting parameters. As shown in Figure , the least-squares fit is quite satisfactory and yields J 1 = −8.17 cm-1, J 2 = 47.23 cm-1, J 3 = −18.08 cm-1, g = 2.12, and zJ = −0.13 cm-1 with the agreement factor25 R = 4.35 × 10-5. The value of zJ = −0.13 cm-1 implies antiferromagnetic couplings among the adjacent Cu4 units, which is consistent with the experimental data. The calculated J values can be correlated with the molecular structure by considering the available exchange pathways between the Cu2+ ions. In the structure, Cu1···Cu2 ···Cu1A are interconnected via a μ 3-OH with the bridging angles of about 96.73−118.79°. The value of the exchange coupling parameter between Cu1 and Cu1A (J 2 = 47.23 cm-1) is reasonable for a double hydroxo bridge with a Cu1···O7···Cu1A of 96.73°. Other bond angles of the μ 3-OH bridging coordination are 110.99 and 118.79°, which indicates the antiferromagnetic interaction (J 1 = −8.17 cm-1, J 3 = −18.08 cm-1). In addition, Cu1···Cu2 are coordinated by the carboxylate group through O1A and O2A in syn−syn mode, reinforcing the antiferromagnetic interaction. There should be a little ferromagnetic exchange taken place between Cu1A···Cu2 (∠Cu1 ···O5···Cu2 = 88.75°). Hence, J 3 is more negative than J 1. The J values are similar to the tetranuclear copper(II) cluster previously reported, with J value −15 to −19 and J‘ value 8−10 cm-1.
elements.clean_text: The experimental data were fitted to eq 1 with g, J 1, J 2, J 3, and zJ as fitting parameters. As shown in Figure , the least-squares fit is quite satisfactory and yields J 1 = -8.17 cm-1, J 2 = 47.23 cm-1, J 3 = -18.08 cm-1, g = 2.12, and zJ = -0.13 cm-1 with the agreement factor25 R = 4.35 × 10-5. The value of zJ = -0.13 cm-1 implies antiferromagnetic couplings among the adjacent Cu4 units, which is consistent with the experimental data. The calculated J values can be correlated with the molecular structure by considering the available exchange pathways between the Cu2+ ions. In the structure, Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 ⋅⋅⋅Cu1A are interconnected via a μ 3-OH with the bridging angles of about 96.73-118.79°. The value of the exchange coupling parameter between Cu1 and Cu1A (J 2 = 47.23 cm-1) is reasonable for a double hydroxo bridge with a Cu1⋅⋅⋅O7⋅⋅⋅Cu1A of 96.73°. Other bond angles of the μ 3-OH bridging coordination are 110.99 and 118.79°, which indicates the antiferromagnetic interaction (J 1 = -8.17 cm-1, J 3 = -18.08 cm-1). In addition, Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 are coordinated by the carboxylate group through O1A and O2A in syn-syn mode, reinforcing the antiferromagnetic interaction. There should be a little ferromagnetic exchange taken place between Cu1A⋅⋅⋅Cu2 (∠Cu1 ⋅⋅⋅O5⋅⋅⋅Cu2 = 88.75°). Hence, J 3 is more negative than J 1. The J values are similar to the tetranuclear copper(II) cluster previously reported, with J value -15 to -19 and J‘ value 8-10 cm-1.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized two 2D coordination polymers, a 2D three-fold interpenetration network of 1 and a 2D bilayer framework of 2, based on copper(II) and trimesic acid. We show that at higher pH conditions, the pH effect on the structure of the complex is not realized by influencing the deprotonation of the organic acid, but rather by introducing hydroxyl groups; the introduction of hydroxyl groups favors the formation of a polynuclear copper(II) coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized two 2D coordination polymers, a 2D three-fold interpenetration network of 1 and a 2D bilayer framework of 2, based on copper(II) and  trimesic acid. We show that at higher pH conditions, the pH effect on the structure of the complex is not realized by influencing the deprotonation of the organic acid, but rather by introducing hydroxyl groups; the introduction of hydroxyl groups favors the formation of a polynuclear copper(II) coordination polymer.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic files in cif format for complexes 1 and 2; experimental and simulated X-ray powder diffraction patterns for 2 and a plot of χ M vs T for 2 are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:
Supporting Information Available 

X-ray crystallographic files in cif format for complexes 1 and 2; experimental and simulated X-ray powder diffraction patterns for 2 and a plot of χ M vs T for 2 are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content:
Syntheses. [Cu 3 (BTC) 2 (H 2 O) 3 (NH 3 ) 4 ] n · 2 n H 2 O (1). To 12 mL of aqua-ethanol (water/ethanol = 1:1 (v/v)) solution was added Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.435 g, 1.8 mmol) and H3BTC (1.0 mmol) while stirring. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 8.3 with NH3·H2O (1.0 mol·L-1), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr and heated in an autoclave at 180 °C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C·h-1. Dark blue crystals of 1 were obtained in 27.6% yield based on H3BTC. Anal. Calcd for Cu3C18H28N4O17 (%):  C, 28.31; H, 3.67; N, 5.24. Found:  C, 27.95; H, 3.69; N, 5.58. FTIR (KBr, cm-1):  3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w.

[Cu 4 (BTC) 2 (OH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (NH 3 ) 4 ] n (2). Complex 2 was prepared in a similar way as illustrated for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction adjusted to 9.2. Prism-like blue crystals of 2 were obtained in 40.2% yield based on Cu(NO3)2·3H2O. Anal. Calcd for Cu4C18H24O16N4 (%):  C, 26.78; H, 2.97; N, 6.94; Found:  C, 26.86; H, 2.92; N, 6.88. FTIR (KBr, cm-1):  3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w. The agreement of experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns with simulated ones for 2 (Supporting Information, Figure ) indicates that a single phase of 2 is obtained.

Syntheses. [Cu  3  (BTC)  2  (H  2  O)  3  (NH  3  )  4  ]   n   ⋅ 2  n  H  2  O (1). To 12 mL of aqua-ethanol (water/ethanol = 1:1 (v/v)) solution was added Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.435 g, 1.8 mmol) and H3BTC (1.0 mmol) while stirring. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 8.3 with NH3⋅H2O (1.0 mol⋅L-1), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr and heated in an autoclave at 180 °C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1. Dark blue crystals of 1 were obtained in 27.6% yield based on H3BTC. Anal. Calcd for Cu3C18H28N4O17 (%): C, 28.31; H, 3.67; N, 5.24. Found: C, 27.95; H, 3.69; N, 5.58. FTIR (KBr, cm-1): 3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w. 

 [Cu  4  (BTC)  2  (OH)  2  (H  2  O)  2  (NH  3  )  4  ]   n    (2). Complex 2 was prepared in a similar way as illustrated for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction adjusted to 9.2. Prism-like blue crystals of 2 were obtained in 40.2% yield based on Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O. Anal. Calcd for Cu4C18H24O16N4 (%): C, 26.78; H, 2.97; N, 6.94; Found: C, 26.86; H, 2.92; N, 6.88. FTIR (KBr, cm-1): 3449s, 1616s, 1554s, 1432s, 1359s, 1250m, 1201m, 1099m, 758w, 721w. The agreement of experimental X-ray powder diffraction patterns with simulated ones for 2 (Supporting Information, Figure ) indicates that a single phase of 2 is obtained.

cln_elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O with trimesic acid (H3BTC) at different pH conditions yield two coordination polymers of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3(NH3)4] n ·2nH2O (1) and [Cu4(BTC)2(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4] n (2). Crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a three-fold parallel interpenetration network and complex 2 shows a two-dimensional bilayer structure. Crystal data are orthorhombic, space group Pbcn, a = 11.242(3) Å, b = 16.963(4) Å, c = 13.898(4) Å, Z = 4 for 1 and monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 18.887(4) Å, b = 10.761(2) Å, c = 14.488(3) Å, β = 126.100(3)°, Z = 4 for 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O with trimesic acid (H3BTC) at different pH conditions yield two coordination polymers of [Cu3(BTC)2(H2O)3(NH3)4] n ⋅2nH2O (1) and [Cu4(BTC)2(OH)2(H2O)2(NH3)4] n  (2). Crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a three-fold parallel interpenetration network and complex 2 shows a two-dimensional bilayer structure. Crystal data are orthorhombic, space group Pbcn, a = 11.242(3) Å, b = 16.963(4) Å, c = 13.898(4) Å, Z = 4 for 1 and monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 18.887(4) Å, b = 10.761(2) Å, c = 14.488(3) Å, β = 126.100(3)°, Z = 4 for 2.

metadata.title:
Construction of a Three-fold Parallel Interpenetration Network and
Bilayer Structure Based on Copper(II) and Trimesic Acid
